sn22.88:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn22.88:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn22.88:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā assaji kassapakārāme viharati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn22.88:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Assaji was staying in a monastery built by a Kassapa, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.88:1.2.comm: Not to be confused with the shameless Assaji of MN 70:4.1, this is probably the early disciple of that name (MN 35:3.1). Assaji was one the group of five mendicants who received the Buddha’s first discourse (Kd 1:6.36.1). Shortly afterwards he inspired Sāriputta with a classic epitome of the teaching (Kd 1:23.2.1).

sn22.88:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā assaji upaṭṭhāke āmantesi:

sn22.88:1.4.pli: “etha tumhe, āvuso, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatha:
sn22.88:1.4.eng: “Please, reverends, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

sn22.88:1.5.eng: ‘Sir, the mendicant Assaji is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn22.88:1.6.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.’

sn22.88:1.8.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena assaji bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
sn22.88:1.8.eng: ‘Sir, please go to the mendicant Assaji out of sympathy.’”

sn22.88:1.9.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato assajissa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.88:1.9.eng: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They did as he asked.

sn22.88:1.11.pli: sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena assaji bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.

sn22.88:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā assaji tenupasaṅkami.
sn22.88:2.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Venerable Assaji.

sn22.88:2.2.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā assaji bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
sn22.88:2.2.eng: Venerable Assaji saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,

sn22.88:2.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ assajiṃ etadavoca:
sn22.88:2.4.eng: But the Buddha said to him,

sn22.88:2.5.eng: “It’s all right, Assaji, don’t get up.

sn22.88:2.6.eng: There are some seats spread out, I will sit there.”

sn22.88:2.7.pli: Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane. Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ assajiṃ etadavoca:
sn22.88:2.7.eng: He sat on the seat spread out and said,

sn22.88:2.8.pli: “kacci te, assaji, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ …pe… paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no abhikkamo”ti?
sn22.88:2.8.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, Assaji; I hope you’re all right. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

sn22.88:3.1.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ …pe… abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no paṭikkamo”ti.
sn22.88:3.1.eng: “Sir, I’m not all right, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing is evident, not its fading.”

sn22.88:3.2.pli: “Kacci te, assaji, na kiñci kukkuccaṃ na koci vippaṭisāro”ti?
sn22.88:3.2.eng: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”

sn22.88:3.3.pli: “Taggha me, bhante, anappakaṃ kukkuccaṃ anappako vippaṭisāro”ti.
sn22.88:3.3.eng: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”

sn22.88:3.4.pli: “Kacci pana taṃ, assaji, attā sīlato na upavadatī”ti?
sn22.88:3.4.eng: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”

sn22.88:3.5.pli: “Na kho maṃ, bhante, attā sīlato upavadatī”ti.
sn22.88:3.5.eng: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”

sn22.88:3.6.pli: “No ce kira taṃ, assaji, attā sīlato upavadati, atha kiñca te kukkuccaṃ ko ca vippaṭisāro”ti?
sn22.88:3.6.eng: “In that case, Assaji, why do you have remorse and regret?”

sn22.88:3.7.pli: “Pubbe khvāhaṃ, bhante, gelaññe passambhetvā passambhetvā kāyasaṅkhāre viharāmi, sohaṃ samādhiṃ nappaṭilabhāmi.
sn22.88:3.7.eng: “Sir, before my time of illness I meditated having completely stilled the physical process. But now I can’t get immersion.

sn22.88:3.8.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, taṃ samādhiṃ appaṭilabhato evaṃ hoti:
sn22.88:3.8.eng: Since I can’t get immersion, I think:

sn22.88:3.10.pli: “Ye te, assaji, samaṇabrāhmaṇā samādhisārakā samādhisāmaññā tesaṃ taṃ samādhiṃ appaṭilabhataṃ evaṃ hoti:
sn22.88:3.10.eng: “There are, Assaji, ascetics and brahmins for whom samādhi is the essence, equating immersion with the ascetic life. They think:
sn22.88:3.10.comm: This is possibly in reference to Godhika, who likewise was distressed by his inability to keep up his meditation (SN 4.23:1.4). States of samādhi are conditioned and dependent on a healthy body, which is why the Bodhisatta needed to eat before he became enlightened (MN 36:33.2). The Buddha urges final Nibbana, which is not a state of consciousness, but freedom from attachment.

sn22.88:3.11.comm: The notion that even an arahant can decline is discussed and rejected at Kv 1.2.

sn22.88:4.7.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’

sn22.88:4.8.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā ‘aniccā’ti pajānāti. ‘Anajjhositā’ti pajānāti. ‘Anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
sn22.88:4.8.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.

sn22.88:4.9.pli: Dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā ‘aniccā’ti pajānāti. ‘Anajjhositā’ti pajānāti. ‘Anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
sn22.88:4.9.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.

sn22.88:4.10.pli: Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, sā ‘aniccā’ti pajānāti …pe… ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti.
sn22.88:4.10.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t relish it.

sn22.88:4.11.pli: So sukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati;
sn22.88:4.11.eng: If they feel a pleasant feeling, they feel it detached.

sn22.88:4.12.pli: dukkhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati;
sn22.88:4.12.eng: If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached.

sn22.88:4.13.pli: adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṃ vedayati, visaṃyutto naṃ vedayati.
sn22.88:4.13.eng: If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached.

sn22.88:4.14.pli: So kāyapariyantikañce vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. Jīvitapariyantikañce vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
sn22.88:4.14.eng: Feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

sn22.88:4.15.pli: ‘Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
sn22.88:4.15.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’

sn22.88:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, assaji, telañca paṭicca, vaṭṭiñca paṭicca, telappadīpo jhāyeyya;
sn22.88:5.1.eng: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.

sn22.88:5.2.pli: tasseva telassa ca vaṭṭiyā ca pariyādānā anāhāro nibbāyeyya.
sn22.88:5.2.eng: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to not being fed.

sn22.88:5.3.pli: Evameva kho, assaji, bhikkhu kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. Jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
sn22.88:5.3.eng: In the same way, feeling the end of the body draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of the body draw close.’ Feeling the end of life draw close, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life draw close.’

sn22.88:5.4.pli: ‘Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn22.88:5.4.eng: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, being no longer relished, will become cool right here.’”

sn22.89:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā therā bhikkhū kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme.
sn22.89:1.1.eng: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

sn22.89:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā khemako badarikārāme viharati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn22.89:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Khemaka was staying in the Jujube Tree Monastery, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn22.89:1.3.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitā āyasmantaṃ dāsakaṃ āmantesuṃ:
sn22.89:1.3.eng: In the late afternoon those senior mendicants came out of retreat and addressed Venerable Dāsaka,
sn22.89:1.3.comm: Dāsaka has a verse at Thag 1.17.

sn22.89:1.4.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, āvuso dāsaka, yena khemako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā khemakaṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadehi:
sn22.89:1.4.eng: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:

sn22.89:1.6.pli: kacci te, āvuso, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti no abhikkamanti, paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no abhikkamo’”ti?
sn22.89:1.6.eng: hope you’re keeping well; they hope you’re all right. They hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.’”

sn22.89:1.7.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā dāsako therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭissutvā yenāyasmā khemako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.89:1.7.eng: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He went to Khemaka and said to him:

sn22.89:1.9.eng: hope you’re keeping well; they hope you’re all right. They hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

sn22.89:1.10.pli: “Na me, āvuso, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ …pe… abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no paṭikkamo”ti.
sn22.89:1.10.eng: “Reverend, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”

sn22.89:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dāsako yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn22.89:2.1.eng: Then Dāsaka went to those senior mendicants and told them what had happened. They said,

sn22.89:2.3.pli: ‘na me, āvuso, khamanīyaṃ …pe… abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati no paṭikkamo’”ti.

sn22.89:2.4.pli: “Ehi tvaṃ, āvuso dāsaka, yena khemako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā khemakaṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadehi:
sn22.89:2.4.eng: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:

sn22.89:2.6.pli: pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.89:2.6.eng: these five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:

sn22.89:2.7.eng: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.89:2.8.pli: Imesu āyasmā khemako pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassatī’”ti?
sn22.89:2.8.eng: Do you regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self?’”

sn22.89:3.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā dāsako therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭissutvā yenāyasmā khemako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā …pe…
sn22.89:3.1.eng: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:

sn22.89:3.5.pli: Imesu āyasmā khemako pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassatī”ti?

sn22.89:3.6.eng: “These five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:

sn22.89:3.7.eng: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.89:3.8.pli: Imesu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu na kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassāmī”ti.
sn22.89:3.8.eng: I do not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self.”

sn22.89:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dāsako yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn22.89:4.1.eng: Then Dāsaka went to those senior mendicants and told them what had happened. They said:

sn22.89:4.5.pli: Imesu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu na kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassāmī’”ti.

sn22.89:4.6.pli: “Ehi tvaṃ, āvuso dāsaka, yena khemako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā khemakaṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadehi:
sn22.89:4.6.eng: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:

sn22.89:4.8.pli: pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.89:4.8.eng: these five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:

sn22.89:4.9.eng: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.89:4.10.pli: No ce kirāyasmā khemako imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassati.
sn22.89:4.10.eng: If, as it seems, Venerable Khemaka does not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self,

sn22.89:4.11.eng: then he is a perfected one, with defilements ended.’”
sn22.89:4.11.comm: They were mistaken, as will be made clear later. Even a stream-enterer does not regard the aggregates as self, in the sense that they cannot form a view to that effect.

sn22.89:5.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā dāsako therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭissutvā yenāyasmā khemako …pe…
sn22.89:5.1.eng: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:

sn22.89:5.5.pli: no ce kirāyasmā khemako imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassati, tenahāyasmā khemako arahaṃ khīṇāsavo”ti.

sn22.89:5.6.eng: “These five grasping aggregates have been taught by the Buddha, that is:

sn22.89:5.7.eng: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.89:5.8.pli: Imesu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu na kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassāmi, na camhi arahaṃ khīṇāsavo;
sn22.89:5.8.eng: I do not regard anything among these five grasping aggregates as self or as belonging to self, yet I am not a perfected one, with defilements ended.

sn22.89:5.9.pli: api ca me, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ‘asmī’ti adhigataṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti na ca samanupassāmī”ti.
sn22.89:5.9.eng: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the conceit ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.”
sn22.89:5.9.comm: The key difference here is between “I am” (asmi), the intuitive sense of being someone, and “I am that” (ayamahamasmi), the identification of that someone with something in particular, namely the aggregates (see MN 47:13.4 and note). | Read avigataṁ per SN 22.47:2.1.

sn22.89:6.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā dāsako yena therā bhikkhū …pe…
sn22.89:6.1.eng: Then Dāsaka went to those senior mendicants and told them what had happened. They said:

sn22.89:6.4.pli: pañcime, āvuso, upādānakkhandhā vuttā bhagavatā, seyyathidaṃ—

sn22.89:6.6.pli: Imesu khvāhaṃ, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu na kiñci attaṃ vā attaniyaṃ vā samanupassāmi, na camhi arahaṃ khīṇāsavo;

sn22.89:6.7.pli: api ca me, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ‘asmī’ti adhigataṃ, ‘ayamahamasmī’ti na ca samanupassāmī”ti.

sn22.89:7.1.pli: “Ehi tvaṃ, āvuso dāsaka, yena khemako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā khemakaṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadehi:
sn22.89:7.1.eng: “Please, Reverend Dāsaka, go to the mendicant Khemaka and say to him:

sn22.89:7.3.pli: yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, asmīti vadesi, kimetaṃ asmīti vadesi?
sn22.89:7.3.eng: when you say “I am”, what is it that you’re talking about?

sn22.89:7.4.pli: Rūpaṃ asmīti vadesi, aññatra rūpā asmīti vadesi,
sn22.89:7.4.eng: Is it form or apart from form?

sn22.89:7.8.pli: viññāṇaṃ asmīti vadesi, aññatra viññāṇā asmīti vadesi.

sn22.89:7.9.pli: Yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, asmīti vadesi. Kimetaṃ asmīti vadesī’”ti?
sn22.89:7.9.eng: When you say “I am”, what is it that you’re talking about?”

sn22.89:8.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā dāsako therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭissutvā yenāyasmā khemako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ etadavoca—
sn22.89:8.1.eng: “Yes, reverends,” replied Dāsaka. He relayed the message to Khemaka, who replied:

sn22.89:8.9.pli: Yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, ‘asmī’ti vadesi, kimetaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesī”ti?

sn22.89:8.10.eng: “Enough, Reverend Dāsaka! What’s the point in running back and forth?
sn22.89:8.10.comm: The reason for the extended back and forth is not exactly clear. Perhaps the senior monks initially sent a messenger so as to not overburden the sick monk with many visitors, and got caught up in an unintended discussion.

sn22.89:8.12.eng: I’ll go to see the senior mendicants myself.”

sn22.89:9.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā khemako daṇḍamolubbha yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā therehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn22.89:9.1.eng: Then Venerable Khemaka, leaning on a staff, went to those senior mendicants and exchanged greetings with them.

sn22.89:9.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ therā bhikkhū etadavocuṃ:
sn22.89:9.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. They said to him:

sn22.89:9.3.eng: “Reverend Khemaka, when you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?

sn22.89:9.4.eng: Is it form or apart from form?

sn22.89:9.9.pli: Yametaṃ, āvuso khemaka, ‘asmī’ti vadesi, kimetaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadesī”ti?
sn22.89:9.9.eng: When you say ‘I am’, what is it that you’re talking about?”

sn22.89:9.10.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ, āvuso, rūpaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadāmi; napi aññatra rūpā ‘asmī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.89:9.10.eng: “Reverends, I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to form, or apart from form.

sn22.89:9.11.eng: I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to feeling …

sn22.89:9.14.pli: na viññāṇaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadāmi; napi aññatra viññāṇā ‘asmī’ti vadāmi.

sn22.89:9.15.pli: Api ca me, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ‘asmī’ti adhigataṃ ‘ayamahamasmī’ti na ca samanupassāmi.
sn22.89:9.15.eng: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the conceit ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.

sn22.89:10.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, uppalassa vā padumassa vā puṇḍarīkassa vā gandho.
sn22.89:10.1.eng: It’s like the scent of a blue water lily, or a pink or white lotus.

sn22.89:10.2.pli: Yo nu kho evaṃ vadeyya: ‘pattassa gandho’ti vā ‘vaṇṇassa gandho’ti vā ‘kiñjakkhassa gandho’ti vā sammā nu kho so vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
sn22.89:10.2.eng: Would it be right to say that the scent belongs to the petals or the stalk or the pistil?”
sn22.89:10.2.comm: Prefer vaṇṭa (“stalk”) over vaṇṇa (“color”), though both are possible.

sn22.89:10.4.eng: “Then, reverends, how should it be said?”

sn22.89:10.5.pli: “‘Pupphassa gandho’ti kho, āvuso, sammā byākaramāno byākareyyā”ti.
sn22.89:10.5.eng: “It would be right to say that the scent belongs to the flower.”

sn22.89:10.6.pli: “Evameva khvāhaṃ, āvuso, na rūpaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadāmi, napi aññatra rūpā ‘asmī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.89:10.6.eng: “In the same way, reverends, I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to form, or apart from form.

sn22.89:10.7.eng: I don’t say ‘I am’ with reference to feeling …

sn22.89:10.10.pli: na viññāṇaṃ ‘asmī’ti vadāmi, napi aññatra viññāṇā ‘asmī’ti vadāmi.

sn22.89:10.11.pli: Api ca me, āvuso, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu ‘asmī’ti adhigataṃ ‘ayamahamasmī’ti na ca samanupassāmi.
sn22.89:10.11.eng: For when it comes to the five grasping aggregates I’m not rid of the conceit ‘I am’. But I don’t regard anything as ‘I am this’.

sn22.89:11.1.pli: Kiñcāpi, āvuso, ariyasāvakassa pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni pahīnāni bhavanti, atha khvassa hoti: ‘yo ca pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu anusahagato asmīti māno, asmīti chando, asmīti anusayo asamūhato.
sn22.89:11.1.eng: Although a noble disciple has given up the five lower fetters, they still have a lingering residue of the conceit ‘I am’, the desire ‘I am’, and the underlying tendency ‘I am’ which has not been eradicated.

sn22.89:11.2.pli: So aparena samayena pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassī viharati—
sn22.89:11.2.eng: After some time they meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.

sn22.89:11.3.pli: iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
sn22.89:11.3.eng: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

sn22.89:11.7.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
sn22.89:11.7.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the disappearance of consciousness.’

sn22.89:11.8.pli: Tassimesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassino viharato yopissa hoti pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu anusahagato ‘asmī’ti, māno ‘asmī’ti, chando ‘asmī’ti anusayo asamūhato, sopi samugghātaṃ gacchati.
sn22.89:11.8.eng: As they do so, that lingering residue is eradicated.

sn22.89:12.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, vatthaṃ saṅkiliṭṭhaṃ malaggahitaṃ. Tamenaṃ sāmikā rajakassa anupadajjuṃ.
sn22.89:12.1.eng: Suppose there was a cloth that was dirty and soiled, so the owners give it to a launderer.

sn22.89:12.2.pli: Tamenaṃ rajako ūse vā khāre vā gomaye vā sammadditvā acche udake vikkhāleti.
sn22.89:12.2.eng: The launderer kneads it thoroughly with salt, lye, and cow dung, and rinses it in clear water.

sn22.89:12.3.pli: Kiñcāpi taṃ hoti vatthaṃ parisuddhaṃ pariyodātaṃ, atha khvassa hoti yeva anusahagato ūsagandho vā khāragandho vā gomayagandho vā asamūhato.
sn22.89:12.3.eng: Although that cloth is clean and bright, it still has a lingering scent of salt, lye, or cow dung that had not been eradicated.

sn22.89:12.4.pli: Tamenaṃ rajako sāmikānaṃ deti. Tamenaṃ sāmikā gandhaparibhāvite karaṇḍake nikkhipanti.
sn22.89:12.4.eng: The launderer returns it to its owners, who store it in a fragrant casket.

sn22.89:12.5.pli: Yopissa hoti anusahagato ūsagandho vā khāragandho vā gomayagandho vā asamūhato, sopi samugghātaṃ gacchati.
sn22.89:12.5.eng: And that lingering scent would be eradicated.

sn22.89:12.6.pli: Evameva kho, āvuso, kiñcāpi ariyasāvakassa pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni pahīnāni bhavanti, atha khvassa hoti yeva pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu anusahagato ‘asmī’ti, māno ‘asmī’ti, chando ‘asmī’ti anusayo asamūhato.
sn22.89:12.6.eng: In the same way, although a noble disciple has given up the five lower fetters, they still have a lingering residue of the conceit ‘I am’, the desire ‘I am’, and the underlying tendency ‘I am’ which has not been eradicated.

sn22.89:12.7.pli: So aparena samayena pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassī viharati.
sn22.89:12.7.eng: After some time they meditate observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.

sn22.89:12.8.pli: ‘Iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo;
sn22.89:12.8.eng: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the disappearance of form.

sn22.89:12.12.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
sn22.89:12.12.eng: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the disappearance of consciousness.’

sn22.89:12.13.pli: Tassa imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassino viharato yopissa hoti pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu anusahagato ‘asmī’ti, māno ‘asmī’ti, chando ‘asmī’ti anusayo asamūhato, sopi samugghātaṃ gacchatī”ti.
sn22.89:12.13.eng: As they do so, that lingering residue is eradicated.”

sn22.89:13.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, therā bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.89:13.1.eng: When he said this, the senior mendicants said to Venerable Khemaka,

sn22.89:13.2.pli: “na kho mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ khemakaṃ vihesāpekhā pucchimha, api cāyasmā khemako pahosi tassa bhagavato sāsanaṃ vitthārena ācikkhituṃ desetuṃ paññāpetuṃ paṭṭhapetuṃ vivarituṃ vibhajituṃ uttānīkātuṃ.
sn22.89:13.2.eng: “We didn’t want to trouble Venerable Khemaka with our questions. But you’re capable of explaining, teaching, asserting, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing the Buddha’s instructions in detail.

sn22.89:13.3.pli: Tayidaṃ āyasmatā khemakena tassa bhagavato sāsanaṃ vitthārena ācikkhitaṃ desitaṃ paññāpitaṃ paṭṭhapitaṃ vivaritaṃ vibhajitaṃ uttānīkatan”ti.
sn22.89:13.3.eng: And that’s just what you’ve done.”

sn22.89:14.2.pli: Attamanā therā bhikkhū āyasmato khemakassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanduṃ.
sn22.89:14.2.eng: Satisfied, the senior mendicants approved what Venerable Khemaka said.

sn22.89:14.3.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne saṭṭhimattānaṃ therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsu, āyasmato khemakassa cāti.
sn22.89:14.3.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty senior mendicants and of Venerable Khemaka were freed from defilements by not grasping.

sn22.9:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, form of the past and future is impermanent,

sn22.9:1.4.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītasmiṃ rūpasmiṃ anapekkho hoti;
sn22.9:1.4.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple is not concerned with past form,

sn22.9:1.5.eng: doesn’t look forward to enjoying future form,
sn22.9:1.5.comm: In similar contexts, anapekkha (“concern”) and abhinandati are regularly oriented towards the past and future respectively. Nanda and its variants straddle the meanings of “take pleasure” and “crave”. Here the prefix abhi- conveys the sense of “facing towards” in the sense “look forward to enjoying”.

sn22.9:1.6.pli: paccuppannassa rūpassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn22.9:1.6.eng: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding present form.

sn22.9:1.11.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītesu saṅkhāresu anapekkho hoti;

sn22.9:1.13.pli: paccuppannānaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn22.9:1.14.eng: Consciousness of the past and future is impermanent,

sn22.9:1.16.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītasmiṃ viññāṇasmiṃ anapekkho hoti;
sn22.9:1.16.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple is not concerned with past consciousness,

sn22.9:1.17.eng: doesn’t look forward to enjoying future consciousness,

sn22.9:1.18.pli: paccuppannassa viññāṇassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hotī”ti.
sn22.9:1.18.eng: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding present consciousness.”
